Title: Dew Heater Bands - (Various Sizes)
Body (HTML):
If the optics fog up, this normally means an early end to what could have been a successful astronomy session and there's nothing more frustrating for an Astronomer or Astrophotographer when this happens on rare crystal clear nights. Heater bands reduce the risk of dew on the lens or on the corrector plate by slightly heating the front lens of your telescope just slightly above the surrounding air temperature which prevents the dew settling on the lens.

A heater controller is also required for these heater bands which allows you to regulate the temperature and therefore achieve an optimal result with a minimum amount of power. You can also combine the heating sleeves with dew shields to further protect your lens or corrector plate from dew formation.

Features:

  • Optimal heat utilization. On the outside, the cuffs are insulated to prevent the wasteful radiation of heat outwards.
  • Particularly flexible due to the elasticated velcro fastener, making it possible to use it on different tubes.

Specs:

  • Power consumption: 12V DC, 4.2W - 350mA

Note: Heat Controller Power Supply required - (Sold Seperately).

Title: 4 Port Dew Heater Controller
Body (HTML):
The Astrozap dual-channel controller uses pulse-width modulation technology. Each channel controls two outputs of a total of four outputs. Each channel is able to maintain a duty cycle of 5% at low setting to 95% at high setting. The Astrozap dew regulator is designed to operate at 12 volts DC and should never be operated at any other voltage. The total current capacity for all four outputs is 5 amps - We recommend using Astrozap Heater bands however other brands can be used once they are a similar rating.

The controller is supplied with a cable about 1.8 meters long, which is equipped with a cigarette lighter plug. A 5-amp fuse is integrated in the connector. The red power LED indicates that the controller is being powered and the two red lights on the outputs indicate the power level of each channel. The brighter the red LEDs, the longer the duty cycle for this channel. When it is set to the lowest setting, it is effectively turned off. It also includes a 2-inch Velcro strap for attaching the controller to a suitable area of your telescope mount.

Specs:
  • Voltage input: 12V DC
  • Voltage output: 12V DC
  • Maximum current: 5 A (fuse in the plug)
  • Power range: 5% to 95%
  • Number of channels: 2
  • Power port: Cigarette lighter plug
  • Length of power cord: approx. 1.8 m
  • Heater output ports: RCA sockets
  • Number of output ports: 4 (2 per channel)

Title: Telescope Dew Shield - (Large 314mm)
Body (HTML):
Glass surfaces such as telescope lenses pointing to the clear sky are prone to having dew forming on the lens during the night - especially if its humid. They also tend to capture stray light, which reduces the contrast of the target.

As many astronomers and astrophotographers have experienced, on clear nights, dew is often a real problem and if it forms on your lens it can render your nights observing session over. After only a very short time, the optics can start fogging, making viewing or photography impossible. A good dew shield reduces the risk of fogging and extends the observing time. Note: on extremely humid nights, dew heaters will also be required. Dew shields are not required for Newtonian reflectors.

Lateral stray light from street lights can also enter the lens which reduces contrast and often cause unwanted reflections in photographs. These dew shields are also blackened out inside with non reflective felt, to help prevent stray light from entering the telescope.

Features:

  • Dew shield for larger OTA's (314mm)
  • The velcro fasteners are sewn and cannot detach. The dew shields themselves are made from weather-proof and non-ageing plastic.
  • These dew shields are extra flexible, the retentive area for the Velcro is much broader than the from many other designs. This offers a larger retentive area and also a better adaption to the diameter of your telescope.
  • Once attached to the tube, they hold very well. The contact surfaces to the tube are coated with a non-slip foam rubber.
  • They can be combined with dew heaters on extremely humid nights.

Title: ZWO ASI 294MC Pro - Colour
Body (HTML):
ASI cameras are renowned for excellent features and superior image quality with modern CMOS sensors installed. The ASI294MC-P camera uses the state-of-the-art "back-illuminated" Sony IMX294CJK sensor.

Sony specifies a sensor diagonal of 21.63 mm. However, measurements by ZWO have shown a true diagonal of 23.2 mm. The 4.3 µm pixels of the ZWO ASI294MC make this camera an all-rounder with highest sensitivity for short exposure times.

Advantages and features of the ASI MC294MCPro color camera:
  • USB 3.0 for a fast download - can also be used with USB 2.0
  • DDR3 memory buffer to help improve data transfer reliability. Additionally, the use of a memory buffer minimizes amp-glow, which is caused by the slow transfer speeds when the camera is used with a USB 2.0 port.
  • Powerful Peltier cooling up to 45 °C below environment.
  • Powerful Peltier cooling up to 35 °C below ambient
  • Sensitive CMOS sensor with 23.2 mm diagonal - 11.7 megapixels
  • Good resolution through 4.63 µm pixels
  • Comes with AR protection window - full transmission also in IR. If infrared should be blocked, an IR-cut filter is necessary.
  • Distance from T2 connection thread (female) to camera sensor: 17.5 mm
  • Very high sensitivity - QE more than 75% - ideal astronomy camera for dim objects
  • 14bit ADC
  • HCG mode - if gain is higher than 120 (12 dB), read noise is reduced below 2e- - result: low-noise images despite extremely high sensitivity.
  • Full well capacity 63700e - even bright stars do not burn out anymore, you get a better signal-to-noise ratio.
ASI294MC Pro has the same mechanics as ASI1600 Pro. There are four screws that seal the sensor chamber and the camera design has been extensively tested and is very stable. Even when used in higher humidity environments, ASI294MC Pro will still work well without dew problems.

USB 3.0 Port & USB2.0 HUB:
  1. USB 3.0 Port: Provide 5Gb bandwidth to make it possible for ASI294 Pro to run at 16 fps (14bit, normal mode) or 19 fps (12bit, high speed mode) at full resolution(11.7Mega).
  2. USB 2.0 HUB: can connect with various accessories, such as filter wheel, guide camera and electronic focuser, so you can better manage your cables. The ASI294 Pro includes two short 0.5m USB 2.0 cables. The integrated USB 2.0 hub is powered by the external power source if you connect one.

Title: Explore Scientific Deep Sky 16MP Astro Camera - Colour
Body (HTML):
This high resolution and very capable deep sky Astro camera comes with a large Panasonic CMOS sensor and active camera cooling.

With the new Explore Scientific Deep Sky Astro camera you get a modern complete package for the comfortable shooting of astro photos and videos. Finally, an easy-to-use camera for capturing galaxies, star clusters, the moon and even planets with high resolution and very low sensor noise. Thanks to the fast USB 3.0 computer interface, all image data is transferred within a seconds. Long waiting times are now a thing of the past.

Simply connect the camera to your telescope using the T2 female thread (M42.0.75mm) or the supplied 2" (50.8mm) plug-in adapter and after installing the drivers and the included 'Explore Capture' recording and editing software, you are ready to take your Astro photos to the next level.

The Explore Capture Pro software included not only offers the basic functions required for image and video capture, but also many helpful special functions for image post-processing and camera setup. Functions such as live image display, exposure settings, white balance, dark image print, stacking, time-lapse recording and so much more can be configured separately.

Choose to use the automatic settings to produce absolutely fantastic results without any previous knowledge or simply switch off the automatic settings and adjust the individual professional settings to your own preference - Its up to you.

The new Explore Deep Sky Camera has a highly sensitive and very low-noise Panasonic CMOS sensor which can also be cooled down to 40°C below ambient temperature by the two-stage thermoelectric cooling. In contrast to normal DSLR cameras, this guarantees much lower noise and fewer hot pixels in your shots. This results in images that are not only much sharper and more brilliant, but also contain more usable image information.

Through the controlled setting of the desired camera temperature, you can now produce dark frames under reproducible shooting conditions at any time. The large-format CMOS sensor with 21.9mm diagonal also allows large image fields and makes the adjustment and centering of objects considerably easier. 

The camera has a built-in USB hub with 2 x USB2.0 ports at the rear. Connect your additional Auto-guider camera or motor focus etc. via a short USB cable and reduce the risk of cable spaghetti and cable breaks. Separate cable connections between your accessories and your computer are also no longer necessary.

Title: ZWO ASI 2600MC Pro - Colour
Body (HTML):
The ASI 2600 MC Pro is a powerful color astro camera using the color sensor in APS-C format with an extremely high sensitivity and 16 bit data depth. This means that even with longer exposure times, the stars no longer burn out and you get a much better dynamic range in your images.

    One of the outstanding features of the ASI 2600MC Pro however is the sensational light sensitivity and the QE of 80%. Thanks to the back illumination technology and the very low amplifier glow, this camera is very well suited for all astronomical applications - Particularly for deep sky astrophotography.

    The camera has a 26MP sensor with a small pixel size of 3.76um, yet it accommodates an impressively large well depth of 50 ke-. As one of the few CMOS astronomy cameras with 16-bit ADC on the market, ASI2600MC Pro was developed with the optimal characteristics for astrophotography in mind. This 16bit ADC is not a CCD 16bit ADC, it can really achieve a dynamic range output of 14 stop, which will significantly improve the image sharpness and contrast, and also create smoother and more natural colour transitions.

    The ASI2600MC Pro also comes with the polyamide heating element that can avoid any condensation problems on the camera sensor. The anti-dew heater, heats up the protective screen slightly to avoid condensation problems. The power of the anti-dew heater is about 5W. It can be switched on and off in the software to save electricity.

Title: ZWO ASI 533MC Pro - Colour
Body (HTML):
The ASI533MC Pro is a powerful color astro camera using the latest generation sensor technology. The color sensor with a diagonal of approx. 16 mm can be used on almost any telescope.
Due to the square shape, the corrected image field of the telescope is optimally used which even allows many telescopes without a corrector to be used. One of the outstanding features of the ASI 533MC Pro however is the sensational light sensitivity and the QE of 80%. Thanks to the back illumination technology and the very low amplifier glow, this camera is very well suited for all astronomical applications - Particularly for deep sky astrophotography.

Main features at a glance:
  1. USB 3.0 for a quick download - can also be operated with USB 2.0 - DDR3 memory buffer for stable data transfer with USB2.0 - this minimizes amplifier glow.
  2. Powerful Peltier cooling up to -35 °C below ambient.
  3. One of Sony's most light-sensitive CMOS sensors
  4. High resolution through 3.76 μm pixels - ideal for fast and sharp telescopes, such as APO's, Hyperstar, Celestron Faststar, fast Newtonian telescopes.
  5. Includes AR clear glass filter - full passage even in infrared. If the IR is to be blocked, an IR cut filter is required.
  6. Distance T2 connection thread (female thread) to the camera sensor: 17.5 mm
  7. Distance front surface to sensor (when using the male thread): only 6.5 mm.
  8. High sensitivity - QE over 80 % - ideal astronomy camera for faint objects
  9. 14-bit ADC - this allows you to achieve a depth similar to CCD cameras, but with much higher sensitivity
Areas of Application:
Deep sky images (nebulae and galaxies): Due to the high sensitivity, nebulae and galaxies are imaged after just a few seconds and the camera can be cooled down to -35 °C below ambient conditions which further reduces the already low noise level. By up-regulating the GAIN (comparable to the ISO setting for digital DSLR cameras), you can reduce the exposure times to less than 30 seconds - This helps to reduce the problems associated with seeing conditions and tracking errors.

For the Moon and Planetary images, extremely short exposure times are also possible due to camera's high sensitivity. Due to the high resolution of the sensor, many details can be imaged a shorter focal length - Video capture is also possible.

Important: external power supply required:
This camera requires 1 amp minimum (even during uncooled operation), which is a problem for USB sockets on computers, because they are only designed for 900 mA, i.e. 0.9 Amps, therefore a 12V power supply is required to use this camera (sold separately).

Title: Explore Scientific Deep Sky 7.1MP Astro Camera - Colour
Body (HTML):
This high resolution deep sky camera incorporates a large 'Sony Exmor IMX428 CMOS' sensor and active cooling and is ideal for telescopes with short and moderate focal lengths.

The Explore Scientific 7.1MP Astro camera comes in a modern complete package for the comfortable imaging of a wide range of night sky targets. This easy-to-use camera is ideal for capturing galaxies, star clusters, the moon and even planets with an extremely high sensor sensitivity and very low sensor noise. The high sensitivity enables very short exposure times and the freezing of the air turbulence (seeing) in planetary images. Thanks to the fast USB 3.0 computer interface, all image data is transferred to your storage device within seconds.

Simply connect the camera to your telescope using the T2 female thread (M42.0.75mm) or the supplied 2" (50.8mm) plug-in adapter and after installing the drivers and the included Explore Capture recording and editing software, you are ready to start imaging.

The Explore Capture pro software included, not only offers the basic functions required for imaging and video capture, but also many helpful special functions for image post-processing and camera setup. Functions such as live image display, exposure settings, white balance, dark image print, stacking, time lapse recording and much more can be configured individually. This sophisticated software makes your entry into astrophotography much easier and using the automatic default settings you can produce stunning results without any previous knowledge.

The Explore Scientific deep sky camera has a highly sensitive and very low-noise Sony Exmor IMX428 CMOS sensor which is additionally cooled down to 40°C below ambient temperature by the two-stage thermoelectric cooling. In contrast to normal DSLR cameras, this guarantees much lower noise and fewer hot pixels in your shots. The images are not only much sharper and more detailed, but also contain more usable signal information. As this camera is cooled, you can carry out your dark and bias frame calibrations at any time. The large-format CMOS sensor with 17.6mm diagonal also allows large image fields and makes framing objects so much easier.

The camera has a built-in USB hub with 2 x USB2.0 ports at the rear. Connect your additional auto guider camera or motor focus etc. via a short USB cable and reduce the risk of cable spaghetti and cable breaks. Separate cable connections between your accessories and your computer are no longer necessary. To protect the camera when not in use, a sturdy hard case is also included.

Title: ZWO ASI 2600MM Pro - Mono
Body (HTML):
The ASI 2600 MM Pro is a powerful mono astro camera using with a sensor using APS-C format with an extremely high sensitivity and 16 bit data depth. This means that even with longer exposure times, the stars no longer burn out and you get a much better dynamic range in your images.

        One of the outstanding features of the ASI 2600MM Pro however is the sensational light sensitivity and the QE of 91%. Thanks to the back illumination technology and the very low amplifier glow, this camera is very well suited for all astronomical applications - Particularly for deep sky astrophotography.

        The camera has a 26MP sensor with a small pixel size of 3.76um, yet it accommodates an impressively large well depth of 50 ke-. As one of the few CMOS astronomy cameras with 16-bit ADC on the market, ASI2600MM Pro was developed with the optimal characteristics for astrophotography in mind. This 16bit ADC is not a CCD 16bit ADC, it can really achieve a dynamic range output of 14 stop, which will significantly improve the image sharpness and contrast, and also create smoother and more natural colour transitions.

        The ASI2600MM Pro also comes with the polyamide heating element that can avoid any condensation problems on the camera sensor. The anti-dew heater, heats up the protective screen slightly to avoid condensation problems. The power of the anti-dew heater is about 5 W. It can be switched on and off in the software to save electricity.

Title: ZWO ASI 6200MC Pro - Colour
Body (HTML):
The ZWO ASI6200MC Pro is a full-frame OSC Astrocamera with extremely high light sensitivity. The camera can be used on all well-corrected telescopes and is a real lightweight at only 700 grams.

Full-frame and high resolution:
The Sony IMX455 sensor offers true full-frame with 24x36 mm dimensions and a diagonal of 43.3 mm. With 3.76 μm pixels, even fine details, such as in galaxy arms, can be resolved. A gigantic field and a high resolution - that's what the 62 MP sensor offers.

Back Illumination Technology:
Sony's rear-exposed CMOS image sensor improves sensitivity and noise reduction – the key factors in improving image quality, while radically realigned the basic pixel structure from front to back exposure. The advantages of CMOS image sensors, such as low power consumption and high operating speed, have been retained.

Backside exposure improves light capture while increasing the amount of light. This makes significantly shorter exposure times possible and leads to improved quantum efficiency of up to 91%. Sony has developed a unique photodiode structure and an on-chip lens optimized for rear-exposed structures, resulting in higher sensitivity and lower random noise without light by reducing noise, dark current and defective pixels compared to the traditional front-exposed
structure.

No amplifier glow:
Conventional CMOS sensors produce a weak infrared light source during operation, which is often seen in the corners of uncalibrated images as signs of the "glow of the amplifier". Since the ASI6200MC Pro uses a zero-amp glow circuit, you don't have to worry about the amp glow or amplifier glow even when using highly amplified, long-exposed images.

Built-in anti-dew heater:
  • The ASI6200 Pro comes with the polyimide heating element, which can avoid any condensation problems.
  • The anti-dew heater, which fits completely on the protective screen, heats it up a bit to avoid condensation problems.
  • The power of the anti-dew heater is about 5 W. It can be switched on and off in the software to save electricity.
Important: external power supply required:
This camera requires 1 amp minimum (even during uncooled operation), which is a problem for USB sockets on computers, because they are only designed for 900 mA, i.e. 0.9 Amps, therefore a 12V power supply is required to use this camera (sold separately).

Title: ZWO ASI 120MM Mini
Body (HTML):
ZWO ASI120 mini - the compact and powerful SW astro camera and autoguiding camera. This small new planetary camera and guiding camera has improved electronics and the sophisticated software to produce the highest sharpness on the moon and planets.

You can also look forward to point-shaped stars during guiding, because the ASI120MM mini is a very capable and fast autoguider.

The ASI120MM mini as a camera for the moon and planets:
The high resolution of 1280 x 960 pixels and the fine 3.75 μm pixels create sharp clear images of objects in the solar system due to the high light sensitivity of the sensor. This allows you to gather lots of data with extremely short exposure times.

Video astronomy with the ASI120MM:
With 35 frames per second at full resolution, you can produce a beautiful flight videos over the lunar surface, or produce ultra-sharp planetary images.

The ASI120MM mini as an effective autoguider:
With this camera, autoguiding is extremely easy. Weighing only 60 grams, the camera does not load the focuser with extra weight. Even with small guide telescopes or with off-axis guiders, the camera will always find a suitable guide star. This makes pin point stars the standard, even with a longer exposure times.

Due to the high resolution, you can track telescopes up to 10" aperture with a 50 mm viewfinder / Mini Guidescope.
The ST4 level autoguider interface allows you to easily connect the camera to your mount by using the autoguider interface. The ST4 cable is included with the camera.

The ASI120MM mini is suitable for a number of guiding software packages including - PHD Guiding, Guidedog, Metaguide, Guidemaster (Freeware) or AstroArt, MaxIm DL.

Title: Bresser HD Moon & Planetary Camera - Colour
Body (HTML):
Bresser HD Moon and Planetary camera with ST4 autoguider function.
This camera is an ideal entry point into the world of astrophotography. The camera is perfect for getting detailed photos of a wide number of celestial objects including the Moon, the Planets or even Star Clusters.

Equipped with the new highly sensitive SONY IMX225 CMOS color sensor, the Bresser HD Moon & Planetary camera delivers amazingly good image results thanks to
very short exposure times, even with simple telescope equipment. In addition to this, it can also be used as an auto-guider camera when connected to an ST4 port.

The particularly low noise level of this new chip from Sony, ensures exceptionally high quality and no additional cooling is required. Due to the high native pixel resolution of 1280 x 980, you can image very beautiful photos of the moon, but also detailed planetary photos with larger suitable telescopes.

The included ToupSky professional software not only offers the necessary basic functions for imaging and video recording, but also many helpful special functions for image post-processing and setting up for use as an auto-guider. Functions such as live image display, exposure settings, white balance, dark image print, stacking, timelapse shots and much more can be configured individually.

This camera has 1.25'' receptacle, 1.25'' filter thread (M28.5 x 0.6) and C-mount thread (1"x1/32").

  • Image sensor: SONY IMX225 CMOS color sensor

  • Adjustable exposure times: 105ms to 16min

  • Megapixels: 1.2 MP
  • Sensor size: 4.8 x 3.6 mm
  • Pixel size: 3.75μm x 3.75μm
  • Bit depth: 8/12 bits unactivatable
  • ST-4 compatible autoguider: Yes
  • CNC manufactured housing made of aluminum
  • Fuse loop on the camera body

  • Camera connection to PC: USB 2.0
  • C-mount extension sleeve with 1.25" filter thread included
  • No IR filter in front of the sensor
  • Operating System: Windows 10 & 11
  • ASCOM and WDM drivers included

Title: ZWO ASI 533MM Pro - Mono
Body (HTML):
ZWO ASI533MM Pro - powerful mono astro camera with the latest generation sensor. This monochrome sensor with a diagonal of approx. 16 mm can be used on almost every telescope. Due to the square shape, it even allows the use of many larger telescopes without a corrector.

A special feature of the ASI533MM Pro is the zero-amp glow circuit, which eliminates the amplifier glow that occurs with longer exposure times. This would brighten areas of the image at longer exposure times, particularly around the corners. The electronics are also designed to reduce the effect of external stray light, so you can take longer exposures under light-polluted skies.

One of the outstanding features of the ASI 533MM Pro is its sensational light sensitivity. The QE of 80% thanks to back illumination technology along with the very low amplifier glow make this camera very suitable for all astronomical applications, but especially for deep-sky astrophotography.

Advantages and features of the ASI 533MM Pro camera:
  • USB 3.0 for fast download - can also be used with USB 2.0
  • DDR3 memory buffer for stable data transfer with USB2.0 - This minimizes amplifier glow
  • Powerful Peltier cooling up to 35°C below ambient conditions
  • One of Sony´s most light-sensitive CMOS sensors
  • High resolution by 3.76 µm pixels - ideal for fast and sharp telescopes like APO's, Hyperstar, Celestron Faststar, Newtonian telescopes etc.
  • Supplied with AR clear glass filter - full transmission also in infrared. If the IR is to be blocked, an IR cut filter is required.
  • Distance T2 connection thread (female thread) to camera sensor: 17.5 mm
  • Distance front surface to sensor (using male thread): only 6.5 mm
  • High sensitivity - QE over 80% - ideal astronomy camera for low-light objects
  • 14-bit ADC. Similar depth to CCD cameras, but with a much higher sensitivity.
Application areas of the camera:

Deep-sky images (nebulae and galaxies):
Due to the high sensitivity, nebulae and galaxies are imaged after only a few seconds. The camera can be cooled up to 35°C below ambient temperature. By raising the Gain level (comparable to the ISO setting for digital SLR cameras), you can reduce exposure times to less than 30 seconds. Effects caused by air turbulence or inaccuracies in tracking are therefore dramatically reduced.

Lunar and planetary images:
Extremely short exposure times due to high sensitivity freeze the air turbulence. Due to the high resolution of the sensor, many details can be imaged even with a shorter telescope focal length. Video 'Lucky Imaging' astrophotography is also possible.

Back illumination technology:
Sony's back-illuminated CMOS image sensor improves sensitivity and noise reduction, which are the key factors to enhancing image quality. This retains the advantages of traditional CMOS image sensors such as low power consumption and high-speed operation.

This allows significantly shorter exposure times and leads to an improved quantum efficiency of 80%.

Zero amp glow:
Traditional CMOS sensors produce a weak infrared light source during operation quite often seen in the corner of uncalibrated images as the tell tale signs of 'amp glow'. As the ASI533MM Pro uses zero amp glow circuitry, you won't have to worry about amp glow even when using high gain, long exposure imaging.

Important: external power supply required!
Please notice that all ZWO cameras with a cooler need to be connected to an external 11-15 V power supply to work. Even when the cooler is not being used the power supply must be used for the camera to operate.

Good storage is an important factor in the prevention against dew and also extends the life span of the camera. Always ensure your camera is stored in a cool dry place and any excess moisture from dew or frost is removed.

  • Sensor: Sony Mono IMX533 square back-illuminated CMOS
  • Sensor size: 11.31mm x 11.31mm - 15.97mm diagonal
  • Pixel size: 3.76 µm
  • Pixel number: 9 megapixels, 3008x3008
  • ADC: 14 bit
  • Cooling: Powerful Peltier cooling
  • Full well: 50ke
  • Readout noise: 1.0 to 3.8e
  • Sensitivity: Peak 80% QE
  • Frame rate at maximum resolution: approx. 20fps (approx. 54fps at Full HD)
  • Power consumption: 12V, 3A

Title: ZWO ASI 183MC Pro - Colour
Body (HTML):
The ZWO ASI183MC uses the modern Sony Exmor R BSI IMX183 color sensor and contains around 20 million pixels. Due to the pixel size of only 2.4 µm, the resolution of this camera is sensational.
One of the outstanding features of the ASI183 is the sensational light sensitivity. It has a QE of 84%, due to the Back Illumination technology, and the very low amplifier glow make the camera very well suited for all astronomical applications, but above all for deep-sky astrophotography.

This "single shot" color camera offers several advantages compared with monochrome cameras. Many imagers prefer not to follow through the laborious L-RGB technique for beautiful colored nebula or planetary images. Color cameras offer a the chance to obtain beautiful images in fewer sessions and without having to constantly change filters. Compared to a standard DSLR camera, the ASI183MC offers much higher light sensitivity, a smoother image and much more depth.

Additional Features:
  • USB 3.0 for quick download - can also be used with USB 2.0
  • DDR3 memory buffer to help improve data transfer reliability. Additionally, the use of a memory buffer minimizes amp-glow, which is caused by the slow transfer speeds when the camera is used with a USB 2.0 port.
  • Powerful Peltier cooling up to 45°C below ambient.
  • One of the most light-sensitive CMOS sensors from Sony with 15.9mm diagonal and 20 megapixels
  • Extremely high resolution thanks to the 2.4µm pixels - ideal for fast and sharp telescopes like Apos, Hyperstar, Celestron Faststar, fast Newtonian telescopes etc.
  • Comes with AR protect window - full transmission also in infrared. If IR should be blocked, an IR block filter is needed.
  • Distance T2-thread (female) to camera sensor: 17.5mm
  • High sensitivity - QE up to 84% - ideal astronomy camera for dim objects
  • 12 bit ADC
Application ranges of this camera:

Deep sky images (nebulae and galaxies): Due to the high sensitivity, nebulae and galaxies are captured after only a few seconds. By cooling down the camera up to 45°C below ambient, the already low levels of noise can be further reduced. By increasing gain (like the ISO setting of DSLR cameras), you can also reduce exposure times to below 30 seconds if necessary

Solar, lunar and planetary images: Extremely short exposure times (due to high sensitivity) freeze the seeing. Through the high resolution of the sensor, many details can be reproduced even at shorter focal length. Video capture is also possible.

Important: An external power supply is required!
Please notice that all ZWO cameras with cooler need to be connected to an external 11-15 V power supply to work. Even when the cooler is not being used the power supply must be used for the camera to be reliably recognized by the software.

Title: Explore Scientific Deep Sky 26MP Astro Camera - Colour
Body (HTML):
This extremely high-resolution deep sky camera from Explore Scientific comes with a large SONY EXMOR IMX-571 APS-C CMOS sensor and active cooling. The extremely high sensitivity is achieved thanks to the SONY back illumination technology. Thanks to the fast USB 3.0 computer interface, all image data is transferred within seconds, reducing the need for high buffering or delay times.

Simply connect the camera to your telescope via female T2 thread (M42, 0.75mm) or via the supplied 2" (50.8 mm) plug-in adapter and then install the drivers as required and you're ready to go.

The included EXPLORE Capture professional software not only offers the necessary basic functions for image and video recording, but also includes many special functions for image post-processing and camera setup. Features such as live image display, exposure settings, white balance, dark image print, stacking, timelapse shooting and much more can be individually configured.

This Explore Scientific Deep Sky Astro camera has a highly sensitive and very low-noise SONY EXMOR IMX-571 APS-C CMOS sensor, which can be additionally cooled down to 40°C below ambient temperature by the two-stage thermoelectric cooling. This guarantees far less noise and fewer hot pixels in your shots compared to normal DSLR cameras. As a result, your images are not only much sharper and detailed, but simply containmore usable image information for post processing. Due to the controlled setting of the desired camera temperature,
dark frames can be created at any time after the imaging session. The large-format CMOS sensor with a diagonal of 28.3mm also allows a wider image FOV and greatly simplifies the setting and centering of objects.

The backlit EXMOR CMOS sensor increases quantum efficiency up to 80% at 533nm, which means an extremely high luminous efficiancy and therefore particularly bright and high-contrast photos.

The camera also has a built-in USB hub on the back with 2 x USB 2.0 ports. This allows you to Connect additional accessories such as an autoguider camera or auto-focusser etc. via short USB cable and thus reduce the risk of Cable clutter and cable breaks.

A sturdy hard case is also included for the camera.

Title: ZWO ASI 662MC - Colour
Body (HTML):
The ZWO ASI662MC is a color USB 3.0 Astro Camera with passive Air-Cooling.

This astro camera is equipped with a modern 1/2.8" sensor with 1920*1080 pixels and provides an extremely smooth image without amplifier glow thanks to the modern Starvis-2 technology (back-illumination), making it ideal for the following applications:

  1. Detailed planetary and Lunar photography (as well as Solar photography with a suitable solar filter).
  2. Photography of (small) brighter nebulae and star clusters with a max exposure time up to 2000 seconds.
  3. Infrared photography to reduce the influence of seeing, thus sharper luminance channel
  4. Autoguiding camera (autoguiding port is available)
  5. EAA (electronically assisted astronomy) for planets, moon and sun
Lunar and planetary photography:
Due to the fine 2.9 μm pixels, you achieve a very high resolution already from f/10, which makes the use of Barlow lenses and converter systems less necessary.

EAA (electronically assisted astronomy):
The high resolution, combined with a high frame rate of 108 fps at full resolution (RAW8 format), allows real-time observation of planets as well as details on the moon and sun. This makes it possible to observe together in a group on a computer screen for example.

Use as autoguider:
The ASI662MC is a lightweight with only 126 grams and offers the ST-4 autoguiding interface. A 2 meter long autoguiding cable is also included.

AR-coated clear glass filter protects the sensor from dust:
The clear glass filter prevents dust from getting to the sensor. It also lets UV and infrared through, so you can also do infrared photography with the camera. You have full control over what light hits the sensor with the right choice of contrast filters, nebula filters, IR pass filters, or UV/IR blocking filters.

Air cooling - reduces sensor temperature:
The sensor heats up during the exposures. The PCS dissipates heat from the sensor via a heat conducting pad. The sensor temperature is thus reduced by up to 15 degrees Celsius compared to cameras without PCS.

Very high sensitivity for short exposure times:
One advantage of the back-illuminated CMOS sensor is the lower readout noise and improved sensitivity. In particular, Sony uses STARVIS-2 technology in the IMX662 sensor, which provides excellent low-light visibility. You can achieve a very high light output in astro imaging and realize high image quality not only in visible light, but also in the near infrared range (to reduce seeing). In addition, the low readout noise and the high full-well capacity ensure a higher dynamic range.

The ASI662MC is not only ideal for Planetary and Lunar imaging, but can also be used as a live streaming camera or as an all-sky camera for observing or monitoring weather conditions.

The HCG mode:
The camera has a built-in HCG mode that can effectively reduce readout noise at high gain and maintain the same wide dynamic range that you would expect at low gain. When the gain is 150, the HCG mode will turn on automatically. This results in readout noise below 1.45 e- while the dynamic range can still reach almost 12.5 f-stops.

Camera Specification:
  • Sensor: Sony 1/2.8" CMOS IMX662AAQR-C color sensor
  • Resolution: 1920*1080 pixels, 2.07 megapixels
  • Pixel size: 2.9 μm
  • Sensor size: 5.568mm x 3.132mm
  • Diagonal: 6.45mm (1/2.8")
  • Capture speed: up to 107.6 FPS at 10 bit
  • Exposure time: from 32 μs - 2000 s
  • ROI: Supported
  • ST4 autoguider port: Yes
  • Distance from T2 thread to sensor: 12.5mm
  • Shutter type: Rolling shutter
  • Protective window: AR coated, full IR transmission
  • Connection: USB3.0/USB2.0
Whats included:
  1. ASI camera
  2. Adapter T2 (M42x0.75) on 1.25" 1.25"
  3. Adapter T2 to CS mount (mounted) Wide field lens (mounted)
  4. USB 3.0 cable ST4 cable
  5. Quick Start Guide

Title: ZWO ASI 2600MC DUO - Colour
Body (HTML):
The ASI2600MC Duo combines imaging and guiding sensors in one compact body. The main sensor is the Sony IMX571 sensor with a native 16-bit ADC, 14 stops dynamic range and 3.76 µm square pixels. The readout noise is as low as 1.0e and the full well capacity reaches an incredible level of 73ke. And on top of all this it has no amp glow!

    The guide sensor is the type 1/1.8 SC2210 with excellent NIR sensitivity. The sensor size is 7.68mm x 4.32mm. It has 4µm x 4µm pixels with an array of 1920 × 1080 and a full depth of 8780e. The stars on the corner of the guide images affected by reducers back focus distance might not appear very round however this is not due to the sensor tilt and it will not affect normal use.

    Two-in-one design:
    Thanks to the compact design, the ASI2600MC Duo only needs one USB cable for control. It reduces potential cabling issues and improves setup speeds. You don´t need a separate OAG and guiding camera.

    The main sensor:
    The main sensor which is the IMX571 features an APS-C format & 26MP total pixels. The size of the sensor is 23.5mm in width x 15.7mm in height, and the diagonal is 28.3mm. The 3.76µm x 3.76µm small pixel size accommodates an impressive full depth of 50ke and with the new hardware technology, it can even be extended to 73ke.

    Guide sensor:
    The SC2210 sensor was taken from the ASI220MM Mini camera and features very high sensitivity. The QE peak value reaches 92% at 500nm and the readout noise is as low as 0.6e. As this is a new generation of guide sensor, it has achieved great results in guiding, proven by hundreds of astrophotographers worldwide.

    The USB 3.0 cable operates both sensors (Main and Guide sensor). The guide sensor can then be selected in PHD2, for example, and the IMX571 sensor in the imaging software that you are using.

    Special Features:

    STARVIS technology:
    ASI2600MC DUO is based on Sony's STARVIS technology. Sony's back-illuminated CMOS image sensor improves sensitivity and noise reduction - the key factors to enhancing image quality.

    Native 16bit ADC:
    This 16-bit ADC is not a CCD 16-bit ADC. It can really achieve a dynamic range output of 14 stops, which will significantly improve the image sharpness and contrast, and also create smoother and more natural color transitions.

    FPS:
    ASI2600MC Duo's max FPS in RAW 8 mode at full resolution is 15 fps, which is even quicker compared to ASI2600MC Pro.

    Extended full well mode:
    The full well capacity of ASI2600MC Duo is extended to 73ke, which is x1.46 more than ASI2600MC Pro.

    USB 3.0 & 512 MB DDR3 buffer:
    With the use of the USB 3.0 cable and 512MB DDR3 buffer, ASI2600MC Duo provides a stable and secure data transmission that can effectively avoid frame-dropping issues during long exposures.

    No amp-glow:
    Traditional CMOS sensors produce a weak infrared light source during operation quite often seen in the corner of uncalibrated images. This is the tell-tale sign of amp glow. As the ASI2600MC Duo uses zero-amp glow circuitry so you won´t have to worry about amp glow even when using high gain, long exposure imaging.

    QE (Quantum efficiency):
    Based on ZWO's testing results, the QE peak value of ASI2600MC Duo is over 91%.

    Two-stage TEC cooling:
    Thanks to the two-stage TEC cooling, ASI2600MC Duo can lower the CMOS sensor temperature to more than 35 degrees Celsius below ambient temperature, which can greatly reduce dark current generation and sensor noise even during extended exposure times.

    * The Delta T35 °C is tested at 30°C ambient temperature. It might reduce downwards when the cooling system is working for a long time. Also, as the ambient temperature falls, the Delta T would also decrease.

    Dark current noise:
    The dark current noise of the ASI2600MC Duo is extremely low. Even with moderate cooling, you get a very low-noise image.

    Anti-Dew heater:
    There is a polyimide heater completely fitting the protective window in the ASI2600MC Duo camera. It can help avoid any potential annoying dew or icing issues depending on the environment in which you capture images. The power of the heater is around 5W. You are free to turn it off anytime in your photography software if you want to save power.

    Important: external power supply required!
    This camera requires a 1 amp power supply even during uncooled operation, which can be a problem for USB ports on computers, because they are generally only rated for 900 mA (0.9 A). Stable operation of the camera is therefore only possible with an external 12V power supply.

    Practical Storage advice: 
    Storage of cameras and accessories, especially in our latitudes, the nights are often very humid. This humidity condenses on your camera, eyepiece or filter when they come into the warm interior of your home after imaging. Cooled cameras are especially affected by this. Good storage is an important prevention mechanism against dew and also extends the life span of your equipment.

    After use, put the camera immediately into its Protect Case and ideally add some silica gel. During storage, the silica gel will suck the moisture out of the camera. At the same time, the penetration of humid room air is prevented. Dry storage even allows the small dry tablets in cooled cameras to partially regenerate. Your camera or accessories are always ready for you in optimal condition. Silica Gel is available here:

    The cameras are not airtight, so if the camera remains on the telescope, it is exposed to moisture. The small amount of desiccant in the camera can protect the sensor and the inside of the protective glass from moisture for the duration of the exposure, but not for days on end. Moisture problems can be the result. A simple trick is to stretch a plastic bag around the focuser to which the camera is attached so that no air can get in. Silica gel is placed in a small cloth bag inside the plastic bag. This will also create a "dry climate zone" for the camera on the telescope. This allows you to leave the camera on the telescope for a few days for an imaging session lasting several days.

    Guiding without ST-4 Port:
    This camera has no ST-4 autoguider port, so you have to connect the mount directly to the PC.

    Camera Spec:

    • Sensor: Sony IMX571 (back-illuminated CMOS color sensor)
    • Sensor size: 23.5mm x 15.7mm, diagonal 28.3mm
    • Pixel size: 3.76µm
    • Resolution: 26 megapixels
    • Pixel array: 6248 x 4176 pixels
    • Exposure Range: 32µs to 2000s
    • Frame rate: up to 15fps
    • ADC: 16 bit
    • Cooling: Powerful Peltier cooling - 35°C below ambient
    • Full well: 51ke -, up to 73ke - at extended full well mode
    • Readout noise: 1.0 to 3.3e
    • Sensitivity: Peak 91% QE
    • Zero amp glow design: Yes
    • Window type: IR cut
    • Anti-dew measures: Anti-dew heater, 5 W, can be turned off
    • Data interface: USB3.0 (USB2.0 compatible)
    • Power consumption: 12V, 3A (5.5/2.1mm, power supply not included)
    • Guide sensor type: SC2210
    • Dimensions: 7.68mm x 4.32mm
    • Pixe size: 4µm x 4µm
    • Resolution: 1920 × 1080 pixels
    • QE: 92% at 500nm
    • FWC: 8780e
    • Readout noise: 0.6e
    • Telescope connection: M54 x 0.75 female thread
    • Working distance from female thread to sensor: 17.5mm
    • Diameter: 90mm
    • Length: 97mm
    • Weight: 0.8kg

    Whats included:

    1. Camera
    2. M54M-M54F adapter (16.5mm)
    3. M54M-M54F adapter (21mm)
    4. M54M-M48F adapter
    5. Hexagon wrench
    6. USB 3.0 cable (2m) x1
    7. USB 3.0 cable (0.75m) x1
    8. USB 2.0 cable (0.5m) x2
    9. Camera bag
    10. Quick guide

    Download the ASI 2600MC-P Manual here

    Download the latest Camera Driver from ZWO here

Title: ZWO ASI 585MC Pro - Colour
Body (HTML):
ZWO ASI585MC Pro color astro camera with active Peltier cooling is a camera for all astrophotographic applications.

This camera is equipped with a 1/1.2" sensor with 3840x2160 pixels (4K UHD). The modern Sony IMX585 sensor is particularly impressive due to its high resolution (2.9 µm pixels), high frame rate and the complete absence of any amp glow. This makes this camera very interesting not only for planets, the sun and the moon, but also for long exposures (deep-sky photography). The sensor is large enough for many deep-sky objects, yet you can usually manage without a corrector. The ASI585MP Pro is an ideal entry-level camera but also an exciting second camera for dedicated astrophotographers. 

The camera is very well suited for:

  • Lunar and planetary photography with high detail resolution
  • Solar photography (with suitable filter) with high detail resolution
  • Long exposures of nebulae and galaxies
  • Infrared photography to reduce the effects of seeing, resulting in a sharper luminance channel
  • EAA (electronically assisted astronomy) for planets, moon and sun.

This camera is a great alternative to a DSLR and mirrorless camera for deep-sky photography. Even the raw images are of high quality, as the sensor no longer shows any amplifier glow and the images are very smooth and low in noise. Added to this is the powerful Peltier cooling up to 35°C below ambient temperature, which means that low-noise images can be taken even at the height of summer.

Moon and planetary photography:
Thanks to the fine 2.9µm pixels, you can achieve a very high resolution from f/10, which makes the use of Barlow and converter systems superfluous.

EAA (electronically assisted astronomy):
The high resolution, combined with a high frame rate of 47 fps at full resolution (RAW8 format), allows real-time observation not only of planets, but also of the moon and sun due to the relatively large sensor. This means you can observe together in a group - without having to wait until everyone has had a turn!

Anti-reflective clear glass filter protects the sensor from dust:
The clear glass filter prevents dust from penetrating the sensor. It also lets UV and infrared light through so that you can also use the camera for infrared photography. With the right choice of contrast filters, fog filters, IR pass filters or UV/IR blocking filters, you have full control over which light falls on the sensor.

Peltier cooling - reduces the sensor temperature:
The sensor heats up during shooting. Thanks to the controlled Peltier cooling, you can keep the sensor well cooled even at high outside temperatures. At an ambient temperature of 20°C you can cool the sensor down to -15 °C.

Very high sensitivity for short exposure times:
One advantage of the back-illuminated CMOS sensor is the reduced readout noise and improved sensitivity. In particular, Sony uses STARVIS-2 technology with the IMX585 sensor, which ensures excellent visibility in low light. You can achieve a very high light yield in astrophotography and obtain high image quality not only in visible light but also in the near infrared range (to reduce seeing). In addition, the low readout noise and the high full-well capacity ensure a larger dynamic range.

In combination with the large field of view offered by the large sensor format, the ASI585MC is not only ideal for solar, lunar and planetary imaging, but can also be used as a live streaming camera or as an all-sky camera for observing or monitoring weather conditions.

The low noise and anti-amp glow circuit make this Peltier-cooled camera interesting for capturing deep-sky objects such as faint nebulae, star clusters and galaxies.

The HCG mode:
The camera has a built-in HCG mode that can effectively reduce readout noise at high gain while maintaining the same wide dynamic range you would expect at low gain. When the gain is 252, the HCG mode turns on automatically. As a result, the readout noise is only 0.7e-, while the dynamic range can still reach almost 12 f-stops.

Spec:

  • Sensor: Sony 1/1.2 inch CMOS IMX585AAQJ1-C (color)
  • Resolution: 3840 x 2160 pixels, 8.28 megapixels
  • Pixel size: 2.9 µm
  • Sensor size: 11.13mm x 6.26mm
  • Sensor diagonal: m12.84mm
  • Exposure time:m from 32 µs - 2000 s
  • Recording speed: up to 46.9 fps at 4K UHD resolution
  • ROI: Supported
  • Quantum efficiency: 91 %
  • ADC: 12 bit
  • Full well: 40 ke-
  • Antiampglow circuit: Yes
  • Readout noise: 0.7 e-
  • Distance from T2 female thread to sensor: 17.5mm
  • Distance from T2 male thread: 6.5mm (the male thread does not count)
  • Shutter type: Rolling shutter
  • Protection window: AR dust protection window (UV and IR light are transmitted)
  • Connection: USB3.0/USB2.0
  • Bit resolution:    12 bit output (12 bit ADC)
  • Telescope connection: 2" / 1.25" / M42x0.75
  • Size: 78mm diameter and 86mm length
  • Weight: 410 grams

Whats included:

  1. ASI camera cooled, with 11mm T2 ring
  2. Camera bag
  3. USB3.0 cable, 2m
  4. Quick guide (English)
  5. T2 extension (21mm long)
  6. M48 to T2 adapter (16.5mm long)
  7. Adapter from T2 to 1.25" receptacle with filter thread
  8. Cover cap 1.25"

  10. 2x USB 2.0 cable, 0.5m
  11. Flat adapter T2 to 1.25" thread (without optical path)
  12. 4x spacer ring

Title: ZWO ASI 294MM Pro - Colour
Body (HTML):
ZWO ASI294MM Pro - Cooled Mono CMOS Camera.
ASI cameras stand for excellent workmanship and have modern CMOS sensors installed. This versatile camera uses the state-of-the-art "back-illuminated" Sony IMX492 sensor.

Sony specifies a sensor diagonal of 21.63mm. However, due to sensor refinement by ZWO the true diagonal is 23.2mm.

The 4.63µm pixels of the ZWO ASI294MM Pro make this camera an all-rounder with highest sensitivity for short exposure times in deep sky photography. Additionally, binning can be switched off, then the pixel size is only 2.32 µm, which increases the detail resolution - even planets can be photographed extremely well this way.

Advantages and features of the ASI MC294MMPro mono camera:

  • USB 3.0 for a fast download - can also be used with USB 2.0
  • DDR3 memory buffer to help improve data transfer reliability. Additionally, the use of a memory buffer minimizes amp-glow, which is caused by the slow transfer speeds when the camera is used with a USB 2.0 port.
  • Powerful Peltier - Cooling up to 35°C below ambient
  • Sensitive CMOS sensor with 23.2mm diagonal - 11.7megapixels
  • Good resolution through 4.63µm pixels
  • Switchable to 2.32µm pixel size and resolution 8288 x 5644
  • Comes with AR protection window - full transmission also in IR. If infrared should be blocked, an IR-cut filter is necessary.
  • Distance from T2 connection thread (female) to camera sensor: 17.5mm
  • Very high sensitivity - QE up to 90% - ideal astronomy camera for dim objects
  • 14bit ADC
  • HCG mode - if gain is higher than 120 (12dB), read noise is reduced below 2e - Result: low-noise images despite extremely high sensitivity.
  • Full well capacity 66387e - even bright stars do not burn out anymore, you get a much better signal-to-noise ratio.

Application ranges of the camera:
Deep sky images (nebulae and galaxies): Due to the high sensitivity, nebulae and galaxies are captured after only a few seconds. By cooling down the camera up to 35°C below ambient, the already low noise characteristics can be further reduced. By increasing gain (like the ISO setting of DSLR cameras), you can reduce exposure times to below 30 seconds. Effects from seeing or inaccuracies of the drive are therefore eliminated.

Lunar and planetary images: Extremely short exposure times (due to high sensitivity) freeze the seeing. Through the high resolution of the sensor, many details can be reproduced even at shorter focal length. Video astronomy is also possible.

Important: external power supply is required!
Please notice that all ZWO cameras with a cooling system need to be connected to an external 11-15V power supply to work. Even when the cooler is not being used the power supply must be used for the camera to be reliably recognized.

These cameras are not airtight, so if the camera remains on the telescope, it is exposed to moisture. The small amount of desiccant in the camera can protect the sensor and the inside of the protective glass from moisture for the duration of the exposure, but not for days on end. Moisture problems can be the result. A simple trick is to stretch a plastic bag around the focuser to which the camera is attached so that no air can get in. Silica gel is placed in a small cloth bag inside the plastic bag. This will also create a "dry climate zone" for the camera on the telescope. This allows you to leave the camera on the telescope for a few days for an imaging session lasting several days.

In the medium and long term, however, this is no substitute for proper storage in an airtight case with silica gel.

Specs:

  • Sensor: 4/3" CMOS Sony mono IMC492LLJ - back illuminated
  • Resolution: 11.7 megapixels, 4144 x 2822 (2x2 Binning)
  • Resolution: 46.8 megapixels, 8288 x 5644 (1x1 Binning)
  • Pixel size: 4.63 µm (2x2 Binning), 2.32µm (1x1 Binning)

Title: ZWO ASI 175MC - Colour
Body (HTML):
ZWO ASI715MC USB 3.0 color astro camera with passive air cooling.

This astro camera is equipped with a modern 1/2.8" sensor with 3864 x 2192 pixels. In addition to the modern Starvis 2 technology (back illumination), the IMX715 offers an extremely smooth image without amplifier glow (amp glow), and has extremely high resolution (1.4µm pixels). This makes the camera particularly suitable for high-resolution photography Such as:

  • Detailed planetary photography
  • Details of the lunar surface
  • Sun details (with suitable filter)
  • Photography of (small) brighter nebulae and star clusters without power-consuming cooling - exposure times of up to 2000 seconds are possible.
  • Infrared images to reduce the influence of seeing, thus sharper luminance channel
  • Autoguiding camera (autoguiding connection is available)
  • EAA (electronically assisted astronomy) for planets, moon and sun

EAA (electronically assisted astronomy):
The high resolution, combined with a high frame rate of 108fps at full resolution (RAW8 format), allows real-time observation of planets as well as details on the moon and sun. Simply observe together in a group - without having to wait until everyone has had a turn!

Use as Auto-guider:
At only 126g, the camera is a very lightweight. It hardly puts any strain on the focuser. The camera of course offers the ST-4 autoguiding interface. A 2 meter long autoguiding cable is also included in the scope of delivery. Due to the extreme resolution, even small guide scopes can be used, but care must be taken to use good optics so that the advantages of the high resolution can also be utilized.

Anti-reflective clear glass filter protects the sensor from dust:
The clear glass filter prevents dust from penetrating the sensor. It also lets UV and infrared light through so that you can also use the camera for infrared photography. With the right choice of contrast filters, nebula filters, IR pass filters or UV/IR blocking filters, you have full control over which light falls on the sensor.

Air cooling - reduces the sensor temperature:
As with all cameras, the sensor heats up during recording. The PCS dissipates the heat from the sensor via a heat conduction pad. The sensor temperature is therefore reduced by up to 15 degrees Celsius compared to cameras without PCS.

Very high sensitivity for short exposure times:
One advantage of the back-illuminated CMOS sensor is the reduced readout noise and improved sensitivity. In particular, Sony uses STARVIS-2 technology with the IMX662 sensor, which ensures excellent visibility in low light. You can achieve a very high light yield in astrophotography and realize high image quality not only in visible light, but also in the near infrared range (to reduce seeing). In addition, the low readout noise and the high full-well capacity ensure a wider dynamic range.
The low noise and anti-amp glow circuit make this camera very interesting for capturing small deep-sky objects too.

The HCG mode:
The camera has a built-in HCG mode that can effectively reduce the readout noise at high gain while maintaining the same wide dynamic range you would expect at low gain. When the gain is 150, the HCG mode turns on automatically. This results in the readout noise being below 1.4 e-, while the dynamic range can still reach almost 12.5 f-stops.

Spec:

  • Sensor: Sony 1/2.8" CMOS IMX715 Color Sensor
  • Resolution: 3864 x 2192 pixels, 8.46 megapixels
  • Pixel size: 1.45µm
  • Sensor size: 5.6mm x 3.2mm
  • Diagonal: 6.45mm (1/2.8")
  • Frame rate: up to 45.1 FPS at 10 bit
  • Exposure time: from 32µs - 2000 s
  • ROI: Supported
  • ST4 autoguider port: Yes
  • Distance from T2 thread to sensor: 12.5mm
  • Shutter type: Rolling shutter
  • Protection window: AR coated, full IR transmission
  • Connection: USB3.0/USB2.0
  • QE: ~80 %
  • Full well: 6.029 ke-
  • Anti-ampglow circuit: Yes
  • Readout noise: 6.9 e- to 0.8 e-
  • Bit resolution: 12 bit ADC
  • Telescope connection: M42 x 0.75 / 2" / 1.25" (via adapter)
  • Tripod thread: 1/4" on the rear side
  • Dimensions: D 62mm x 37.1mm (without lens)
  • Operating temperature: -5 °C to +50 °C
  • System requirements: USB 3.0 should be supported by the operating system - from Windows 8, Mac OS X 10.8, Linux Kernel 2.6.31 (from Ubuntu 16.04)
  • Weight: 126g

  2. Adapter T2 (M42 x 0.75) on 1.25"
  3. 1.25" cover
  4. Adapter T2 to CS mount (mounted)
  5. Wide field lens (mounted)

Title: ZWO ASI 664MC - Colour
Body (HTML):
ZWO ASI664MC USB3.0 Astro Camera with passive Air-Cooling

This camera is equipped with a modern 1/1.8" sensor with 2704 x 1536 pixels. The IMX664 offers an extremely smooth image without amplifier glow in addition to the modern Starvis-2 technology (back-illumination), but convinces especially with the high resolution (2.9 µm pixels) and the high frame rate. We recommend this camera for:

  • Detailed planetary photography
  • Lunar surface details
  • Sun details (with suitable filter)
  • Photography of (small) brighter nebulae and star clusters without power consuming cooling - exposure time up to 2000 seconds is possible
  • Infrared photography to reduce the influence of seeing, thus sharper luminance channel
  • Autoguiding camera (autoguiding port is available)
  • EAA (electronically assisted astronomy) for planets, moon and sun

Lunar and planetary photography:
Due to the fine 2.9µm pixels, you achieve a very high resolution even from f/10, which even makes the use of Barlow lenses and converter systems unnecessary.

EAA (electronically assisted astronomy):
The high resolution, combined with a high frame rate of 95fps at full resolution (RAW8 format), allows real-time observation of planets as well as lots of details on the moon and sun. Why not observe together in a group - without long waiting times for everyone´s turn!

Use as Auto-guider:
The ASI664MC is a lightweight camera at only 126g. It hardly loads the focuser at all. The camera also has an ST-4 autoguiding interface and a 2 metre long autoguiding cable included.

AR-coated clear glass filter protects the sensor from dust:
The clear glass filter prevents dust from getting to the sensor. It also lets UV and infrared through, so you can also do infrared photography with this camera. You have full control over what light hits the sensor with the right choice of contrast filters, nebula filters, IR pass filters, or UV/IR blocking filters.

Air cooling - reduces sensor temperature:
As with all cameras, the sensor heats up during the exposures. The PCS dissipates heat from the sensor via a heat conducting pad. The sensor temperature is therefore reduced by up to 15 degrees Celsius compared to cameras without PCS.

Very high sensitivity for short exposure times:
One advantage of the back-illuminated CMOS sensor is the lower readout noise and improved sensitivity. In particular, Sony uses STARVIS-2 technology in the IMX664 sensor, which provides excellent low-light visibility. You can achieve a very high light output in astro imaging and also in the near infrared range (to reduce seeing). In addition, the low readout noise and the high full-well capacity ensure a higher dynamic range.

The ASI664MC is not only ideal for planetary and detailed images of the Sun and Moon but can also be used as a live streaming camera or as an all-sky camera for observing or monitoring weather conditions.

The low noise and anti-amp glow circuitry make this camera interesting for capturing deep-sky objects such as faint nebulae, star clusters and galaxies.

The HCG mode:
The camera has a built-in HCG mode that can effectively reduce readout noise at high gain and maintain the same wide dynamic range that you would expect at low gain. When the gain is 252, the HCG mode will turn on automatically. This results in readout noise below 1.0 e- while the dynamic range can still reach more than 11 f-stops.

  • QE: ~91%
  • Full well: 36.5 ke-
  • Anti amp glow circuit: Yes
  • Readout noise: 5.8 e- to 0.46 e-
  • Bit resolution: 12 bit ADC
  • Telescope connection: M42 x 0.75 / 2" / 1.25" (via adapter)
  • Tripod thread: 1/4" at the rear side
  • Dimensions: D 62mm x 37.1mm (without lens)

Title: Bresser HD Deep Sky Camera - Colour
Body (HTML):
The Bresser Full HD Deep Sky Camera with autoguider is a great camera for different types of astrophotography and for use as an autoguiding camera. Its not only suitable for photographing planets, but also for deep-sky objects such as galaxies, nebulae and star clusters.

Dedicated ToupSky Astro Imaging software supports video preview, video recording, video processing, image capture and processing, dark field correction and raw data output. Its easy to use, but with professional results.

One of the main features of the new backlit SONY IMX290 CMOS sensor is its high light sensitivity, which makes it possible to detect deep-sky objects without active cooling. SONY has increased the quantum efficiency at 533nm wavelength up to 77%, which is much better than other CMOS sensors have been able to achieve in the past.

Connect this camera to a guidescope and attach the camera's built-in ST-4 port, directly to your telescope's equatorial mount guide port and you can also use this camera for autoguiding - using many popular audioguiding programs (such as PHD and more). Autoguiding enables you to take accurate pictures with long exposure times of several minutes. Thanks to the extra light-sensitive camera, you now always have a suitable guide star to hand, even using short exposure times. An ST-4 protocol connection cable is also included.

You can use this camera with all guiding telescopes, or off-axis guiders that accept a 1.25" tube, 1.25" filter thread (M28.5x0.6) or C-mount adapter thread (1 "x1 /32").

Important Note:

This is not a stand-alone camera. You always need a Windows 10/11 Laptop or computer to take pictures and for autoguiding.

  • Camera type: Bresser / Touptek GPCMOS02000KPA color
  • Sensor: SONY IMX290 CMOS color, backlit
  • Image and video size: Full HD 1936 x 1096 pixels (video 15FPS)
  • Native sensor size in pixels: 1936 x 1096
  • Exposure times: 66µs to 16min
  • Binning: YES, 2x2

  • Sensor size in mm: 5.6 x 3.1

  • Bit depth: 8/12 switchable

  • CNC milled housing made of aluminum

  • Computer interface: USB 2.0
  • C-mount extension tube with 1.25 inch filter thread included
  • No IR cut filter installed
  • Operating system: WINDOWS 10 + 11
  • ASCOM driver included

Title: ZWO Filter Drawer - M48 (2")
Body (HTML):
This filter drawer allows quick and easy manual filter changes in seconds. With the 2" Filter Holder, this quick release filter drawer is especially useful for astrophotographers who want to change filters (eg. Broadband & Narrowband) during sessions but do not want a large and sometimes heavy filterwheel.

Special features:
  • The optical length is only 21mm. For ZWO cameras, the drawer can simply be used instead of the T2 extension.
  • The filter holder snaps into place magnetically, which guarantees precise positioning of the filter.
  • Thanks to the open design of the drawer, the filter can be easily inserted or removed.
  • The drawer is round and very compact, so it can also be used before the optics, e.g with Hyperstar systems or the Celestron RASA.
  • A filter holder for 2" filters is included.
  • The use of 1.25" filters is also possible with an optional reduction adapter.

  • Connection camera side: T2 male thread - length 4 mm
  • Adapter for 2" filter: With M48x0.75 female thread

Title: Optolong L-Ultimate Dual Narrowband Filter - 2"
Body (HTML):
The Optolong L-Ultimate dual narrowband filter is designed to drastically reduce the effect of light pollution and capture a very specific wavelength of light emitted from deep space emission and planetary nebula. Its two ultra-narrow 3 nm passing bands isolate the nebulae emissions in Ha (red) as well as OIII (green-blue).

This effectively means local light pollution is much less significant and even imaging during a full moon is possible too as all other wavelengths outside of the specific Ha and OIII signal are blocked from entering the camera. The L-Ultimate filter is literally the ultimate filter for astrophotography under urban light polluted skies.

Features:
  • Blocks the artificial light from mercury vapour lamps, both high and low pressure sodium vapour lights and the unwanted natural light caused by neutral oxygen emission in our atmosphere (skyglow).
  • Maximum transmission of the main nebula emission lines at OIII (496 nm and 500 nm) and H-alpha (656 nm)
  • Two transmission bands with a bandpass of 3nm each
  • Designed mainly for astrophotography with color cameras
  • Also helpful with monochrome cameras, no need to change filters for catching both lines
  • Ideal for urban areas with extreme light pollution
  • It incorporates an IR/UV cut filter that is necessary in astrophotography, especially for astronomy cameras that are sensitive to the infrared radiation.
  • Ultra-thin filter cell to maximise the compatibility with most filter wheels.
  • Multi-layered anti-reflection coating
  • No obvious halo around bright stars
  • Cell in an aerometal material, CNC machined, sand blasted, black anodized and laser engraved
  • Includes a PP plastic case, high pressure EVA case lining
The interferential coating is deposited on the substrate using electron-beam gun evaporation with Ion-assisted deposition coating technology. This essentially increases the filter durability and resistance to scratching, as well as stability on CWL (central wavelength) and no deviation affected by temperature changes.

The planetary rotation system offers precision and homogeneity of coatings ensuring high transmission of pass-band and high optical density off-band.

Spec:
  • Transmitted lines: OIII (500.7 nm), H-alpha (656.3 nm)
  • FWHM: 3nm
  • Suitable for: 2" Filter threads
  • Blocking range: 300 - 1000 nm (UV/IR cut)
  • Blocking: >OD4
  • Substrate: Optical glass made by Schott
  • Substrate thickness: 2mm
  • Surface quality: 60/40
  • Optical flatness: λ/4 rms
  • Parallelism: 30 arc sec
  • AR coating: Multi layer
  • Cell: Aluminum, black anodized

Whats included:
  1. L-Ultimate Filter
  2. Protective box, foam lined

Title: Optolong L-eXtreme Dual Narrowband Filter - 2"
Body (HTML):
L-eXtreme Filter is absolutely perfect for deep sky nebula photography from the city as it uses much tighter narrowband limits. The relentless spread or urbanization and its associated light pollution have become a big problem for all amateur astro photographers around the world. One solution is to purchase a Mono camere but this can be extremely expensive and might include the purchase of several types of narrowband filters and a filter wheel.

These filters open up a whole new opportunity for fast newtonian telescopes, double-lens ED refractors or even achromats, allowing for extremely detailed and high class astronomical images even from heavy light polluted cities as it blocks out all artificial light pollution sources as it is a dual narrow bandpass filter, only allowing for the wavelengths of O-III and H-Alpha. This filter is fast bcoming a must have item for serious Astro-imagers using OSC cameras.

The L-eXtreme is a two 7NM narrow bandpass filter which can be used with one-shot color cameras like DSLRs (digital SLR), color CMOS and monochrome CCD cameras. The convenience and cost-effectiveness of this filter allows amateurs to photograph rich emission type nebulas, even in bright, heavily light-polluted skies. The L-eXtreme filter is the best choice for fast optical systems as it isolates the H-Alpha and Oxygen III nebula emission lines so that the contrast and signal-to-noise ratio between these are maximized.

L-eXtreme has a multiple anti-reflective coatings on the optical substrate. The L-eXtreme filter uses a precision coating based on ion deposition coating technology. This ensures durability and scratch resistance as well as stability on the CWL (central wavelength), which is not affected by temperature changes. Absolute precision of the coatings as well as maximum values for transmission in the passband and optical density in the off-band range are guaranteed for all filters.

IMPORTANT WARNING: These nebula filters are NOT designed for observation of the Sun. Do not use this filter to look at the Sun as serious eye damage, blindness as well as damage to equipment may result.

Filter Details:

  • Professional photographic filter for astronomy
  • Improves deep sky emission nebula photography
  • Best choice for extreme light pollution suppression
  • For taking pictures also from highly light-polluted areas
  • Dual-narrow-band filter with high transmission for O-III and H-Alpha lines
  • Does not require very large or extremely expensive telescopes
  • Excellent results also with fast inexpensive newtonian telescopes, double-lens ED refractors or even achromats
  • L-eXtreme filter is the better choice for fast systems at a competitive price
  • CMOS colour cameras can deliver an image quality that comes close to CCD monochrome cameras
  • Filter diameter: 1.25 inches / 31.7 mm
  • Connecting thread: M28x0.6mm
  • Selected optical glass material
  • Spectrum: 300-1000nm
  • Off-Band Blocking: > 99 %
  • Surface Quality: 60/40 (Refer to MIL-O-13830)
  • Fine-optically polished to ensure accurate 1/4 wavefront and highest parallelism over the both surfaces
  • High transmission at major nebula emission lines (i.e. H-alpha 656nm and OIII 496nm & 500nm)
Whats included:
  1. L-eXtreme filter (designed for 1.25" optics)
  2. Dust protection box
  3. Technical Data

Title: ZWO Seestar S50 Filter Holder
Body (HTML):
This 2" filter adapter is specially designed for the ZWO Seestar S50.

Although the Seestar already has a built-in LPS filter for light pollution, in Astrophotography it is often required to use narrowband filters particularly when photographing nebula regions of the galaxy that are rich in Hydrogen Alpha. This adapter allows the use of individual 2" nebula filters, so you can optimally adapt them to your Seestar S50 for Astro photography.

  • Dimensional stability: up to 80°C

Title: Explore Scientific Ha 7nm Filter - 1.25"
Body (HTML):
The Explore Scientific Ha filter is specifically designed for photographing emission nebulae. These objects glow in certain colors, the so-called emission lines. The emission lines are associated with certain chemical elements - and in this case its Hydrogen Alpha.

The Explore Scientific Ha nebula filter blocks all other colors from the light spectrum (and therefore almost all other types of artificial light) and lets only the emission lines of Ha through.

All Explore Scientific nebula filters come with an individual test report - so you can be sure to get high quality filters.

Features:

  • H-Alpha filters are used for astrophotography exclusively
  • Allows photography of emission nebulae that emit red hydrogen light
  • Many of these emission nebulae are only visible across their full spectrum in photos taken with this filter
  • Blocks almost all artificial light, especially from mercury and sodium vapor lamps
  • Transmission bandwidth: 7 nm
  • Suitable for 1.25" Filter threads
  • Allows more contrast and detail when imaging from the city
  • Individual test certificate included to guarantee you receive a premium filter
Whats included:
  1. A 1.25" Ha nebula filter

Title: TS Filter Drawer Housing - T2
Body (HTML):
These filter housings are specially designed for use with either the 2" or 1.25" filter drawers and are really useful for helping you change filters quickly and easily with minimum disruption to your image train.

At only 100g weight and a diameter of 80mm, this quick filter housing is more compact and lightweight than a full sized filter wheel and is ideal for colour astrocam setups where generally single filters are required eg. Broadband & Narrowband.

These filter housings are suitable for use with both the 2" and 1.25" TS filter drawers.

Features:

Title: ZWO LRGB Filter Set - 1.25"
Body (HTML):
ZWO LRGB 1.25" Filter set for astro imaging with MONO CMOS cameras:

The filter set consists of four multi-coated 1.25" interference filters.

The filter set consists of:

  1. 1.25" RGB interference filters red, green, blue
  2. 1.25" UV/IR blocking filter

The filter set is optimally matched to the sensitivity of CMOS sensors, such as the ASI1600MM. The result is images with excellent color weighting and natural colors. Each filter is plane-parallel and the filters are parfocal to each other. Each filter is anti-reflective and has a high-quality coating.

Specs:

  • Connection: 1.25" filter thread
  • Coatings: Multi-coating
  • Design: Multi-layer interference filter

Title: ZWO LRGB Filter Set - 2"
Body (HTML):
ZWO L-RGB Round Filter Set for Astrophotography:
The filter set consists of four multi-coated interference filters. It is optimized for astrophotography with monochrome CCD and CMOS cameras.

The filter set consists of:

  1. Interference Filters Red, Green, Blue (RGB)
  2. UV/IR block filter

The filter set is a good alternative to the usually much more expensive filter sets of other manufacturers and a much better alternative to simple color filters. The transmission of these ZWO filters is considerably higher and the result is a high-contrast image which is very well suited for further processing.

The filter set is optimized for ZWO ASI cameras, but can also be used with other CCD cameras such as ATIK or Moravian.

Specs:

  • Type: Interference filter
  • Connection: 2" filter thread M48 x 0.75
  • Substrate thickness: 1.9 mm

  • Transmission: Over 92%

Title: ZWO Narrowband Filter Set - 1.25"
Body (HTML):
ZWO Narrowband Filter Set for Astrophotography:
Narrowband nebula filters significantly increase the contrast of an object and eliminate light pollution. Due to the bandwidth of 7nm, images are displayed with extremely sharp contrast, even from light polluted cities. ZWO filters are homofocal with each other. The filter set consists of:

ZWO H-Alpha Filter 7nm:
This narrowband nebula filter has a definite pass band around 656 nm. This is the line in which H-II objects (hydrogen nebulae). Transmission in this range is 80%. The filter is the optimal choice for astrophotography as the contrast of nebulae is significantly increased.

ZWO O-III Filter 7nm:
This narrowband nebula filter has a definite pass band around 500 nm. This is the line in which many planetary nebulae light. Transmission in this range is 80%. The filter is the optimal choice for astrophotography as the contrast of the nebulae is significantly increased. This filter is also suitable for visual observation.

ZWO S-II Filter 7nm:
The narrowband nebula filter has a definite pass band around 672 nm and like the O-III this is perfect for many planetary nebulae as well as emission nebulae and supernova remnants shine. Transmission in this range is 80%.

Specs:

  • Type: Nebula filter, interference filter
  • Size: 1.25" mounted in a low-profile filter cell
  • Thickness of the filters: 2 mm

Title: ZWO Motorised Filter Wheel 5 x 2"
Body (HTML):
This ZWO Motorised Filter Wheel is designed to hold 5 unmounted 2" filters.

ZWO´s latest EFW (Electronic Filter Wheel) provides a larger clear aperture than previous models but still only weighs 500g. The filter wheel body is CNC milled from aircraft grade aluminum and is only 20mm thick.

Motor drive:
The core part of the EFW is the stepper motor which has reliable performance and quality that comes from NPM, Japan. This 2" Electronic Filter Wheel can be rotated both clockwise and counter clockwise for the desired filter selection.

There is no need of multiple cables to power this wheel up, just one USB cable does the trick. The maximum power supply of this EFW is approximately 120 mA @ 5 V, which can be operated from most cooled Astrocameras with a USB2.0 port.

Filters:
Accepts 2″ thread-in filters and 50.4 mm ±0.5 mm unmounted filters.
When connected to an ASI6200, the distance from the filter to the sensor is about 18 mm.

Title: M42 Extension Ring Set (5 Extensions)
Body (HTML):
Set of 5 extension tubes with T2 thread on both sides for exact distances and a secure hold of cameras used for astrophotography. This set also comes with a SC to T2 thread adapter.

In astrophotography, most cameras are connected to a telescope via a T2 thread (M42x0.75), which is the most popular international standard. However, in many cases, T2 and T2-ring adapters for connecting telescope focusers to a camera are not the correct focus distance. This is especially important when using correctors, reducers or flatteners in the image train. This extension tube set, which consists of 5mm, 7.5mm, 10mm, 15mm and 30mm tubes, will allow you to obtain almost any distance using various combinations. Each tube has a T2 interior thread on one side and a T2 exterior thread on the other side.

Most telescopes either include a T2 thread adapter, or the eyepiece can be used with a simple T2 thread adapter with a 2" plug-in.
However, Maksutov-Cassegrain, Schmidt-Cassegrain, ACF or Ritchey Chrétien telescopes may use a so-called SC thread. To allow you to use this extension tube set with these telescopes, the set also includes an SC to T2 thread adapter.

Details:
  • 5 T2 tubes with lengths from 5 mm to 30 mm
  • Combination of tubes allows you to obtain distances of 5 mm to 67.5 mm
  • For exact camera distances in astrophotography
Whats included:
  1. 5 x T2 extension tubes (5/7.5/10/15/30 mm)
  2. 1 x SC to T2 thread adapter
